thread.title: 'Generous' extensions granted to tech companies forced to collect metadata, Brandis says
thread.title_full: 'Generous' extensions granted to tech companies forced to collect metadata, Brandis says | afr.com

author: Primrose Riordan
title: 'Generous' extensions granted to tech companies forced to collect metadata, Brandis says
text:
Attorney-General George Brandis says 'generous' extensions will be granted to tech companies forced to collect metadata. Alex Ellinghausen Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan The many technology companies struggling to comply with sweeping metadata retention laws are being offered time extensions, Attorney General George Brandis said.
The laws, which require the companies to retain phone and internet records for all Australians so law enforcement authorities can catch offenders such as terrorists and child abusers are to come into place on Tuesday. Fewer than one in five companies say they are ready .
A survey by the Communications Alliance lobby group found that out of 63 companies over two thirds did not completely understand what they needed to do in order to comply.
Digital liberties groups ramped up public information campaigns teaching citizens on how to keep their information private.
Senator Brandis said the industry's obligations were were very clearly expressed in the law. "It has been very thoroughly discussed with the industry there is an implementation working group comprising of the industry leaders, industry associations and the Attorney Generals Department," he said.
"There is an 18 month period from today [so] companies which are not compliant as of today, which is six months after the legislation can come into force, are able to apply for an extension of their compliance obligation. Those applications will be treated generously."
While the Attorney-General's Department allocated $131.3 million to companies for setting up the systems to retain the data, it is expected the department will keep some of these funds as administrative costs . Senator Brandis said this was still a 'fair' contribution.
More terror measures On Monday night Senator Brandis said he would introduce a law to allow police to detain children as young as 14 under control orders , following the shooting of Curtis Cheng outside Parramatta police station by 15-year-old Farhad Khalil Mohammad Jabar.
"The Parramatta shooting demonstrates that 14 is not too young for these control orders," Senator Brandis said.
Senator Brandis said some safeguards and protections would be offered to all children aged from 14 to 18.
Former Independent Security Legislation monitor Bret Walker told the ABC : "I continue to doubt the usefulness of having this alternative to arresting, charging".
